title: ‘Unbelievable’: Royal Commission into Bondi won’t examine the massacre
description: Sky News host Paul Murray questioned why the Antisemitism and Social Cohesion Royal Commission will not directly probe the Bondi attack.  “The criminal proceedings which are taking place against the alleged gunman, all of that had already begun before the Royal Commission was confirmed,” Mr Murray said.   “We can’t find an awful lot of records of the government or anyone else setting the expectation that the Royal Commission that happened because of Bondi wouldn’t be able to talk about Bondi.  “The informal meeting was held at 10 am on Thursday in the Bondi Pavilion to discuss why the Antisemitism and Social Cohesion Royal Commission will not be able to directly probe the attack that left them scared.”  “Seems to be just about the political solution to the Prime Minister's failures in and around Bondi.”

title: ‘Matter of days’: Iran one week away from nuclear bomb making material
description: Former Israeli minister of strategic affairs Ron Dermer explains the process Iran would have to go through to create a bomb from its enriched uranium.   “Iran is left with a lot of highly enriched Uranium,” Mr Dermer told Sky News host Sharri Markson.   “They have enriched material that could become military grade in a matter of days.  “The 400-plus kilos of highly enriched uranium would have to be removed from Iran and diluted.”

title: ‘Crooked’: Douglas Murray exposes Apple News for excluding right-leaning media
description: Author Douglas Murray criticises Apple News for favouring left-leaning news outlets, claiming to justify the bias on the grounds of “reliability”.  “They think that all of the left-wing publications and platforms are super reliable,” Mr Murray told Sky News host Rita Panahi.  “It’s crooked, it’s unfair, it’s unbalanced.  “If the big tech companies can't take a look at this, I think the US Congress should.”

title: ‘Life and death’: Inside the extraordinary clash over Iran’s nuclear future
description: Former Israeli minister of strategic affairs Ron Dermer details how different Presidents have dealt with the situation in Iran.   “With Obama, he was completely moving in a different direction,” Mr Dermer told Sky News host Sharri Markson.  “It forced the Prime Minister of Israel to actually go to Congress… And oppose the nuclear deal with Iran.   “It was a matter of life and death for the state of Israel.”

title: ‘China dominated purchases’: Foreign investors ‘buying up all the new Aussie homes
description: Sky News host Paul Murray warns foreign investments in Australia are making it harder for Australians to buy homes.   “Foreign investors have put in billions of dollars into the Australian property market since the announcements have been made,” Mr Murray said.  “China dominated the list with a thousand purchases, a combined value of 1.1 billion dollars.  “When everyone opens up the present, there’s an empty box.  “The foreign buyers might not be bidding against you for the existing two-bedroom unit, but guess what they are doing: buying up all of the new ones.”

title: ‘This is a sham’: Aussies struggle to pay power bills
description: Nationals Senator Ross Cadell believes Australians should be more outraged about power bills and electricity prices.  “It’s become so hard for so long that people are getting used to it,” Mr Cadell told Sky News host Paul Murray.  “This is a sham.  “All this is hurting, and people are suffering.”

title: ‘He spent 30 years on death row’: Man freed after wrongfully imprisoned
description: EWTN Broadcaster Colm Flynn discusses the incredible story of Anthony Ray Hinton, who was wrongfully imprisoned for 30 years.   “This is an incredible story, you mentioned the name Anthony Ray Hinton,” Mr Flynn told Sky News host Paul Murray.   “He was 29 in 1985 when one day he was out cutting the grass at his mother’s place, two police officers pulled up, and they accused him of murder.  “Long story short, he was found guilty and sentenced to death.   “He spent 30 years on death row.  “He was released from prison.”

title: Norwood Council ratepayers burdened with $106 million swimming pool renovation debt
description: Sky News host James Macpherson details how ratepayers in the Norwood Council in South Australia are burdened with a $106 million debt from a swimming pool renovation.   “We need you to defend your countrymen colleagues in South Australia, because the Norwood Council in SA have plunged local rate payers,” Mr Macpherson said.  “They have $106 million in debt because of overruns on a swimming pool reno.”

title: ‘Get rid of them’: Julian Leeser blasts university group assessments as ‘unfair’
description: Sky News host James Macpherson details how Shadow Education Minister Julian Leeser is claiming group assessments at universities are “unfair”.  “The Opposition Education Minister Julian Leeser has told university leaders that they need to scrap group assignments,” Mr Macpherson said.  “You’d be familiar with group assignments … every now and again they throw you an assignment that you have to gather together with two or three other classmates and do it together, Julian Leeser says this is typically unfair.”

title: Chalmers to possibly limit negative gearing to a maximum of two investment properties
description: Sky News host Caleb Bond details how the Albanese government may limit Australians to negatively gearing a maximum of two investment properties.   “On the front of the Australian tomorrow, gearing up if the cap fits, oh boy, treasury is examining new rules that would limit Australians to negatively gearing a maximum of two investment properties,” Mr Bond said.  “Jim Chalmers’ department is now reviewing negative gearing limits in addition to considering changes to the capital gains tax discount for existing properties.”

title: ‘Say sorry’: Albanese blasted for not admitting his mistakes
description: Sky News contributor Joe Hildebrand explains why Prime Minister Anthony Albanese seems unable to admit his mistakes.  “There’s two different styles of leadership,” Mr Hildebrand told Sky News host Paul Murray.  “They sort of can’t admit that they’re wrong or say sorry.”

title: ‘Spare me the condensation, old man’: Tame hits back as PM backtracks on ‘difficult’ comment
description: Sky News host Caleb Bond calls out Prime Minister Anthony Albanese for backtracking on comments made about former Australian of the Year Grace Tame.  “Oh, come on, Prime Minister,” Mr Bond said.  “You called her difficult; we all heard it, and most of us agreed with you.  “You said what you said, and you meant it.  “Spare me the condensation, old man.”

title: ‘Naïve” Starmer thrashed over enabling France to send migrants to the UK
description: Broadcaster Esther Krakue slams UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer for his “lack of judgement” and his “naïve” government.   “So far, the UK has handed the French authorities over 700 million pounds which we are still wondering what has been done with that,” Ms Krakue told Sky News Digital Presenter Gabriella Power.   “Their success rate is so low.  “The French don’t want a lot of these migrants, and they’re happy to wring their hands of them.”

title: ‘They wanted privacy’: Shameless opportunism from Harry and Meghan
description: Sky News host Caleb Bond calls out the hypocrisy from The Sussexes, claiming they want privacy whilst putting themselves in the spotlight.  “They left England and the Royal family because they wanted privacy,” Mr Bond said.   “They left and went to California and then spent all their time ever since making sure they have the least privacy possible.  “Then whinging about the fact that they don’t have any privacy”

title: ‘Toxic groom’: MAFS bachelor slammed for not wanting a woke, ugly wife
description: Sky News host Freya Leach questions why the Married at First Sight bachelor has been slammed for wanting traditional values in his wife.  “This season they have a new bachelor on the show,” Ms Leach said.   “The Sydney Morning Herald has labelled him as a toxic groom.  “He wants to be a provider and a protector, and he doesn’t want a woke, ugly wife; what’s so wrong with that?”
